subject: Re: [junit] Re: Changing junit.framework.Assert to instance methods
msgSnippet: David, In your prior email you stated that your tests lean more towards being functional tests.  So I m curious as to why you don t think the following is
messageBody:
David,

In your prior email you stated that your tests "lean more towards being
functional tests." So I'm curious as to why you don't think the
following is adequately addressed by JFunc?

import junit.framework.*;
import junit.extensions.jfunc.*;

public class MultiFailureTest extends TestCase {

public MultiFailureTest(String name) {
super(name);
}
public void testMultipleFailures() {
// use JFuncTestCase, which looks just like JUnit's TestCase, except it
// uses it's own assert class that is non-static
JFuncTestCase test = new JFuncTestCase("multi failure") {
protected void runTest() {
fail("one");
fail("two");
}
};
TestResult result = new TestResult();
test.setFatal(false); // make assertions non-fatal, hence allow
for multiple failures
test.run(result);
assertEquals("number of failures",2,result.failureCount());
}
}

If this feature is useful for unit testing, then by all means put it in
JUnit. If it's not or questionable, put it in JFunc.

-shane

http://jfunc.sourceforge.net
